journal-title-group.journal-title: African Review of Money Finance and Banking

title-group.article-title: GOVERNMENT INTERVENTIONISM, PRIVATISATION AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: A CRITICAL REVIEW OF THE ISSUES

abstract.p: This study has attempted to provide a review of the main issues in the privatisation-government interventionism debate pointing out not only the theoretical arguments but also the empirical supports to these arguments. The study was unable to find any conclusive evidence as to the technical superiority of private enterprises over public enterprises at the same level of operation. It is found that theoretically, the right type of incentives can be created in both public and private enterprises that maximizes efficiency. It is also found that the main determinant of enterprise efficiency is not whether it is publicly or privately owned but how it is managed. The review also revealed that the success of privatisation does not lie in the number of state-owned enterprises that are privatised but in the improved resource allocation, reflected in higher growth, productivity of capital and reduced government budget deficits. We indicated that if the principal objective of privatisation is to increase economic efficiency, the policy priority is not to transfer productive activities to the private sector but to subject state-owned enterprises to competition.
